text: there's a one really important fact when
we look at gaps what we're finding is
that in the world as a whole at least
out of the hundred and thirty four
countries that that we're looking at
ninety six percent of health gaps have
been closed ninety-three percent of
education gaps have been closed and then
only about fifty nine percent of the
economic participation gap and only
eighteen percent of the political
empowerment gap so what we find is that
in generally speaking as a global
average women are starting to be as
healthy and almost as educated as men
and yet they're not being channeled into
the economy and not able to participate
in decision-making so that's an immense
loss for the global economy that's
that's certainly one you know very
striking fact that comes out of the
report at the second though is more good
news and that is you know we are making
progress so when we look at the last
five years of data that we've been
collecting what we find is out of the
hundred and fourteen countries that that
we've covered for the last five years
eighty-six percent have actually made
progress so eighty-six percent of these
countries are moving forward and out of
those some of them are moving forward
very very fast they made gains of 10 or
20 percentage points in terms of closing
their gender gaps and and perhaps even
more encouragingly it's not just the
countries at the top that are making
progress so it's not just Iceland and
Norway and Finland that are moving ahead
it's also some of the countries at the
very bottom so for example Saudi Arabia
is one of the worst ranking countries
and on this index and yet it's also one
of those that's growing the fastest
that's moving forward the fastest
because of a huge investment in terms of
women's education the United Arab
Emirates another country that has made
over the last couple of decades a big
investment in terms of women's education
and is now moving forward because they
made a very conscious effort to remove
the barriers for women's entry into the
workforce and then women's entry into
the political system
sure so you know it's it's it's not by
any means just Iceland so Iceland Norway
Finland Sweden Denmark these are all
countries that for the last hundred
years or so as a part of their
development and growth have made social
inclusion goals a very important part of
that development so that has resulted in
these countries having now not just very
high levels of health and education for
women but very high levels of economic
participation and a lot of that is due
to conscious policies that make it
possible for women and men not just
women to be able to combine their their
family life with their working life and
what they've ended up with is this
virtuous cycle where you have not just
high levels of participation but also
actually higher fertility rates than
most of other Western European countries
so that that's certainly one angle the
other piece is the political empowerment
peace and quite a number of the
Scandinavian countries have put quotas
and targets in place several decades ago
in fact and have now reached a stage
where they no longer need that
stipulation where they no longer even
need that quota because you do have
women in very senior positions in
government
now the United States has actually made
quite a lot of progress over the last
five years and so finally broke into the
top 20 in our 2010 report and and it's
the country that obviously has very high
levels of health and education for women
in at least according to measures that
we're looking at in fact women are now
as we know coming out of university
education and greater numbers than men
are the problem is that that that talent
is not being tapped into at the right
levels so yes women and men are entering
the workforce in similar numbers and
women and men's wages are certainly very
similar at that very entry level and yet
when you go through the ranks of most
companies you're starting lose out and
the middle management you're starting to
lose out a senior managed and by the
time you get to for example CEO level
they're very very few women that are
left there it's a waste of the the
investment that companies have made in
having those women for five or ten years
in their systems and then simply losing
out on that talent because they're
unable to find a mechanism to allow them
to combine work and family
